classification.notes: Primarily used as a topical cosmetic ingredient. Not an FDA-approved therapeutic drug; outcomes depend heavily on formulation and delivery.

status.human_use_note: Copper Tripeptide-1 (GHK-Cu) is widely used topically in skincare. Human evidence is mixed and formulation-dependent. It is not an FDA-approved therapeutic drug.

structure.sequence_oneletter: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.
structure.molecular_formula: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.
structure.structure_image_url: Pep-Talk curation pending: we’re reviewing the evidence and will expand this section soon.

risk.rationale: Topical cosmetic use generally presents low systemic risk. Main uncertainty comes from variable formulations, inconsistent objective outcomes across small human studies, and limited standardized long-term safety characterization across product types.

overview.title: What it is
overview.text: Copper Tripeptide-1 (GHK-Cu) is a copper-binding peptide complex used in topical products for skin appearance and barrier-related goals. Evidence includes small human studies and broader reviews; results may depend on formulation and delivery to target layers.

use_cases.text: These are the most common real-world reasons people look into this peptide, plus the context that tends to matter most (quality, expectations, and safety).
use_cases.title: Use cases (real-world)

use_cases.text: cosmetic interest for skin appearance and texture (topical use common)
discussion around hair/scalp health in cosmetic communities (mixed evidence)
used as a general “skin support” ingredient in some formulations

observed_exposure_ranges.notes: Descriptive only. Products vary widely by formulation and concentration. Not instructions.

developmental_risk_block.text: Developmental exposure may carry higher and less predictable risk than adult exposure. Long-term effects on growth, endocrine signaling, and neurodevelopment are not well studied and may be irreversible.

interaction_summary.text: Interactions here are category flags — they’re meant to help you ask better questions and avoid obvious conflicts. They are not a dosing guide.
interaction_summary.title: Interaction summary

interaction_summary.text: If you’re on cardiovascular, anticoagulant/antiplatelet, serotonergic, or immunomodulating meds/supplements, treat uncertainty as a reason to slow down and verify with a clinician.

current_outlook_bullets: copper Tripeptide-1 (GHK-Cu) is a copper-binding peptide complex used in topical products for skin appearance and barrier-related goals
evidence includes small human studies and broader reviews; results may depend on formulation and delivery to target layers
common biohacker curiosity due to community reports
interest in mechanisms suggested by early evidence
exploration in wellness communities despite evidence limits

evidence.title: Regenerative and Protective Actions of the GHK-Cu Peptide in the Skin
evidence.notes: Review covering skin-related evidence and mechanisms; mixes human, preclinical, and mechanistic data.

evidence.title: Human skin penetration of a copper tripeptide in vitro as a function of skin layer and delivery conditions
evidence.notes: Penetration/delivery study relevant to topical delivery variability.

evidence.title: Effects of topical copper tripeptide complex on photoaged skin (clinical cosmetic study)
evidence.notes: Clinical cosmetic study; objective wrinkle/skin-quality outcomes may be mixed; patient-reported satisfaction may differ from measured changes.

changelog.summary: Initial canonical entry for Copper Tripeptide-1 (GHK-Cu)
changelog.detail: Added topical cosmetic peptide entry with review + delivery evidence + clinical cosmetic study reference; low-risk topical profile with uncertainty penalty due to formulation variability.

practical.bottom_line: GHK-Cu is best known for skin and hair/cosmetic use. It is widely discussed topically; injectable use is higher-risk with less real-world clarity.
benefits: cosmetic interest for skin appearance and texture (topical use common)
discussion around hair/scalp health in cosmetic communities (mixed evidence)
used as a general “skin support” ingredient in some formulations
side_effects_serious: severe allergic reaction symptoms (hives, facial swelling, trouble breathing)
widespread rash or swelling that escalates quickly
who_should_be_cautious: people with copper sensitivity or severe dermatitis history
adolescents (cosmetic use still has limited long-term data)
anyone prone to allergic reactions to skincare actives
